bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul L. Tate, March 3, 1954

div1.p: Hench plans on sending a questionnaire to Tate and will ask him to try to identify buildings in photographs taken at Camp Lazear, Camp Columbia, and Pinar del Rio.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul L. Tate, March 3, 1954
div1.opener:
March 3, 1954
Mr. Paul L. Tate
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley 3, California
My dear Mr. Tate:
div1.p:
I appreciate greatly your letter of February 24. I am in the middle
of an editorial job, writing a paper which must be finished as soon
as possible, but later this spring I hope to write you and ask you a
few questions. I will not bother you to answer them by mail as I hope
to see you and General Truby in San Francisco in June. I want to show
you three or four old pictures of Camp Lazear, Camp Columbia, and so
on and ask you to help identify buildings therein.

I did not recall that you were with Captain Godfrey at Pinar del Rio.
I am very anxious to talk to you about that episode and bring you some
pictures of Pinar del Rio as of 1900, the tent encampment, etc., but
particularly the permanent buildings. I hope you can perhaps recall
(and point out in the photograph) where the little prison was, where
the one soldier got yellow fever and the other two did not. I have
several photographs of the buildings. Did you know that they blew up
some years later in one grand explosion which rocked the little town?
I also have pictures taken after the explosion. I visited Pinar del
Rio a few years ago and will show you what it looks like now.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
